moves.4. Bd3 Bb7 5. O-O Be7 6. c4 O-O 7. Nc3 h: White creates a strong pawn centre.
moves.8... d5 9. cxd5 exd5 10. e5 Ne4 11. Qe2: Black's position has a few targets (g7,h6 and h7) since all of these are on the kingside, a kingside attack is clearly the most logical continuation. The weakness on the b1-h7 diagonal suggests a queen & bishop battery (with the obvious mate threat on h7), but a sacrifice on h6 could also be possible. Whilst White has time since counterattack is a long way away for Black, Black does threat 13...Ba6 to rid White of his strongest piece. This would still be playable e.g. 13.a4 Ba6 14.Bxa6 Qxa6 15.Qxa6 Nxa6 16.a5... With a favourable - if slight - position for White. Nonetheless, White should aim for more in a dominant position such as this....
moves.13. Bb1: (!) Threatening the battery on the b1-h7 diagonal.
moves.13... Ba6 14. Qc2 g6: Here Black sets a trap. If 15.Bxh6?... Then 15...Bxf1 16.Bxf8 Bxg2! And Black shows potential for a counter.
moves.15. Re1: (!) Black is now forced to respond.
moves.15... Kg7 16. Qd2 Rh8: Note how g6 is now weakened.
moves.22... Qf6 23. Nh4 Bd6 24. Qh3 Ne7 25. Nx: Here Black resigned. Note how Black had a vision to remove the d3-bishop which White anticipated fantastically and didn't give his opponent a chance.
